Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Reducing and Managing spring frost damage
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project focuses on maximizing resources for frost defense, reducing yield loss, improving quality, supporting decision-making, and reducing frost management cost for grapes and stone fruits. Cold periods and frost episodes are still one of the worst enemies of grape and stone fruit production worldwide. Grape and orchard production are highly linked to climatic conditions, making sub-seasonal weather variability and its connections to climate change a challenging issue for this economic sector. Growers may presently deploy fossil fuel heaters, sprinkler systems, the downward draft from helicopters and wind machines to fight spring frost damage. These methods are usually costly, some create environmental concerns, and in many cases they may be limited by water availability and area coverage. Altering timing of bud break stages that are susceptible to frost injury appears to be a viable alternative to cope with current and emerging challenges of climate change. The proposed I-Corp program explores implementation and commercialization opportunities of an end-to-end solution. The innovation combines a bioactive, non-toxic biodegradable encapsulation technology (spray) that alters internal grapevine physiology and promotes bud break delay. A predictive analytic system provides recommendations to make informed decisions about frost risk management.

This I-Corps project is based on a series of studies that have combined pruning management, biophysical and biochemical factors influencing the endogenous regulation of bud break, and resistance to cold injury. In addition, the project combines this knowledge with an analytic data platform (software) that will analyze plant development as a function of environmental temperature (phenology), topographic and soil data, at the farm level. Combination with global and regional patterns of climate patterns will aid understanding climate variability at high spatial and temporal scale. This platform will allow better prediction for decision making at the vineyard and orchard level to reduce some of the most significant challenges associated with prediction reliability about bud break and risk of frost. Moreover, this predictive analytic system will be the foundation for continued innovation in tools and services to support decision-making to adapt growing practices, and to preserve sustainability due to already observed and worsening climate change impacts. The I-Corp process will also be used to refine our understanding of customer value, willingness to pay and the cost of the best current alternatives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact of our I-Corps project is to provide environmentally friendly and low-cost technological solutions for the prevention of early spring frost damage at vineyards and to make labor management and mechanized farm operations more efficient.

Evidence is mounting that climate change is creating disruptions in the fruit industry on a global scale. Grape and orchard fruit production are highly linked to climatic conditions, making sub-seasonal weather variability and its connections to climate change an important concern for this economic sector. During our NSF I-Corps identification of customer segments, from April 2018 to September 2019, we tested the overall hypothesis that the wine industry is in need of technological innovations to face the present and future threats of spring frost. We interviewed 110 stakeholders in several sectors of interest including viticulturists, vineyard managers, wineries, agriculture chemical distributing companies, agriculture equipment technology companies, and growers associations. We traveled from the west coast, to Colorado to the Midwest to the east coast in New York. Although for some viticulture areas spring frost is not yet a major concern, the majority of the responses we obtained attest to the market interest and demand for frost protection and confirmed our approach of delaying bud break with a non-toxic and non-hormonal encapsulation technology. All stakeholders cited frost damage among the top weather hazards causing significant crop losses. They all also expressed a sense of urgency for the development of new approaches to better combat the threats imposed by spring frost. In addition, growers said that they would quickly adopt methods to reduce risks associated with spring frost if said methods proved to be viable at the applied level. One of the growers put it this way: ?We need a frost prevention and risk management technology like we need water for our vines and trees.?  For the majority of grape growers we consulted, delaying plant development is considered a novel approach to defend against frost. Early spring is the riskiest time of the season and frost losses can reach up to 90%, especially for early cultivars. As one grower explained, "One of the biggest concerns in our business is spring frost. Even with hail we can defend our vineyards, but with spring frost we still feel many times powerless; we are truly at the mercy of mother nature.?

As an important outcome from our customer discovery we were able to identify an unexpected value proposition. Production of grapes is a labor-intensive effort and many states, including Washington, have reported labor shortages of up to 30% in the last few years.  In the words of one large Washington State grower, ?We cannot find enough labor when it?s time to do shoot thinning, sucker control, spraying, mowing, and more in our vineyards.? In response, vineyards, especially larger ones, are moving quickly toward mechanization, especially in removing adventitious shoots. ?Timing is very important when we use machines,? a vineyard stressed.  Since our technology can delay bud break, it has the potential to allow the reduction in the number of machines needed for shoot thinning and expand the operating window needed for mechanized shoot removal. Thus we determined that there could be another scalable business application for our technology.

Since our proposed technology is ideally applied weeks prior to bud break, this represents a long-term prediction and therefore necessitates the presence of a predictive analytics system to indicate when bud break will occur, coupled with a high probability of frost at critical stages in different environments. Thus we tested the hypothesis that a predictive analytic system can help growers to make decisions and improve frost management efficiency. The majority of growers from the most prominent grape producing regions do not have tools for mid-range prediction of weather/climate that include microclimate data at the plot and plant level. We validated our value proposition of predictions of farm conditions to guide the application of our technology and provide tools for frost management decision making during the entire season, thus filling a big gap in the market.

 

From participation in I-Corps, the team has a better understanding of the challenges and expectation of grape growers regarding adoption of new technologies. , We found that on-site demonstration/validation of our technology is essential for customer acceptance and market expansion.As result of the I-Corps program, the team EL, Manfredo Seufferheld, has launched a startup company and  partner with leading growers to demonstrate measurable reduction in frost damage on their vineyards.
